Package ohos.utils.geo

Class Rect

  • java.lang.Object
    • ohos.utils.geo.Rect
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    Sequenceable

    public class Rect
extends Object
implements Sequenceable
    Represents a rectangle area.

    This class is used to specify the rectangle area on the screen after you draw or outline a rectangle.

    Since:
    5

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class Description
      static class  Rect.RotationEnum
      Indicates the rotation angle.

      • bottom

        public int bottom
        Indicates the position of the Y coordinate on the bottom of the rectangle.

        This variable defines the Y coordinate on the vertical axis where the bottom side of the rectangle locates on the screen.

        Since:

    • Constructor Detail

      • Rect

        public Rect​()
        Default constructor used to create a Rect instance.

        This method is used to define a rectangle object, which is the point in the upper left corner of the screen by default.

        Since:
        5

      • Rect

        public Rect​(int left,
            int top,
            int right,
            int bottom)
        A constructor used to create a Rect instance.

        This method is used to define a rectangle object based on the positions of the four sides in the coordinate space.

        Parameters:
        left - Indicates the position of the X coordinate on the left of the rectangle object.
        top - Indicates the position of the Y coordinate on the top of the rectangle object.
        right - Indicates the position of the X coordinate on the right of the rectangle object.
        bottom - Indicates the position of the Y coordinate on the bottom of the rectangle object.
        Since:
        5

      • verifyRect

        public final boolean verifyRect​()
        Checks whether this Rect object is valid.
        Returns:
        Returns true if the X-axis and Y-axis coordinates of the rectangle's upper left corner are less than those of the rectangle's lower right corner; returns false otherwise.
        Since:
        5

      • getWidth

        public final int getWidth​()
        Obtains the width of a rectangle.

        If the right value of the rectangle is smaller than the left value, a negative value will be returned.

        Returns:
        Returns the width of the rectangle.
        Since:
        5

      • getHeight

        Returns:

        Since:

        public int[] getCenter​()
        Obtains an array of coordinates of the center point of this Rect object.
        Returns:
        Returns the array that contains the coordinates of the center point of this Rect object. The first value represents the value in the X axis, and the second one represents the value in the Y axis.

      • equals

        public boolean equals​(Object object)
        Indicates whether some other object is "equal to" this one.

        The equals method implements an equivalence relation on non-null object references:

        • It is reflexive: for any non-null reference value x, x.equals(x) should return true.
        • It is symmetric: for any non-null reference values x and y, x.equals(y) should return true if and only if y.equals(x) returns true.
        • It is transitive: for any non-null reference values x, y, and z, if x.equals(y) returns true and y.equals(z) returns true, then x.equals(z) should return true.
        • It is consistent: for any non-null reference values x and y, multiple invocations of x.equals(y) consistently return true or consistently return false, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the objects is modified.
        • For any non-null reference value x, x.equals(null) should return false.

        The equals method for class Object implements the most discriminating possible equivalence relation on objects; that is, for any non-null reference values x and y, this method returns true if and only if x and y refer to the same object (x == y has the value true).

        Note that it is generally necessary to override the hashCode method whenever this method is overridden, so as to maintain the general contract for the hashCode method, which states that equal objects must have equal hash codes.

        Overrides:
        equals in class Object
        Parameters:
        object - the reference object with which to compare.
        Returns:
        true if this object is the same as the obj argument; false otherwise.
        See Also:
        Object.hashCode(), HashMap

      • hashCode

        public int hashCode​()
        Returns a hash code value for the object. This method is supported for the benefit of hash tables such as those provided by HashMap.

        The general contract of hashCode is:

        • Whenever it is invoked on the same object more than once during an execution of a Java application, the hashCode method must consistently return the same integer, provided no information used in equals comparisons on the object is modified. This integer need not remain consistent from one execution of an application to another execution of the same application.
        • If two objects are equal according to the equals(Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce the same integer result.
        • It is not required that if two objects are unequal according to the Object.equals(java.lang.Object) method, then calling the hashCode method on each of the two objects must produce distinct integer results. However, the programmer should be aware that producing distinct integer results for unequal objects may improve the performance of hash tables.

        As much as is reasonably practical, the hashCode method defined by class Object does return distinct integers for distinct objects. (This is typically implemented by converting the internal address of the object into an integer, but this implementation technique is not required by the Java™ programming language.)

        Overrides:
        hashCode in class Object
        Returns:
        a hash code value for this object.
        See Also:
        Object.equals(java.lang.Object), System.identityHashCode(java.lang.Object)

      • toString

        public String toString​()
        Returns a string representation of the object. In general, the toString method returns a string that "textually represents" this object. The result should be a concise but informative representation that is easy for a person to read. It is recommended that all subclasses override this method.

        The toString method for class Object returns a string consisting of the name of the class of which the object is an instance, the at-sign character `@', and the unsigned hexadecimal representation of the hash code of the object. In other words, this method returns a string equal to the value of: 

         getClass().getName() + '@' + Integer.toHexString(hashCode())
        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        a string representation of the object.

        Obtains the intersection rectangle of this Rect object and the rectangle determined by left, top, right, and bottom.
        Parameters:
        left - Indicates the X-axis coordinate of the upper left corner of the specified rectangle.
        top - Indicates the Y-axis coordinate of the upper left corner of the specified rectangle.
        right - Indicates the X-axis coordinate of the lower right corner of the specified rectangle.
        bottom - Indicates the Y-axis coordinate of the lower right corner of the specified rectangle.
        Returns:
        Returns the intersection rectangle of the specified rectangle and this Rect object.
        Since:
        5

      • obtainIntersectRect

        public Rect obtainIntersectRect​(Rect rect)
        Obtains the intersection rectangle of the specified rectangle and this Rect object.
        Parameters:
        rect - Indicates the specified rectangle.
        Returns:
        Returns the intersection rectangle of the specified rectangle and this Rect object.
        Since:
        5

      • reorder

        public void reorder​()
        If the rectangle is illegal, swap the left, right, or top and bottom coordinates to make the rectangle legal.
        Since:
        5

      • getIntersectRect

        public boolean getIntersectRect​(Rect rectA,
                                Rect rectB)
        Checks whether two specified rectangles intersect, and sets this Rect to that intersection if they intersect.
        Parameters:
        rectA - Indicates one rectangle to check.
        rectB - Indicates the other rectangle to check.
        Returns:
        Returns true if two specified rectangles intersect; returns false otherwise.
        Since:
        5

      • convertRectToValue

        public String convertRectToValue​()
        Obtains the string converted from the rectangle based on the defined format.
        Returns:
        Returns the string converted from the rectangle.
        Since:
        5

      • convertValueToRect

        public static Rect convertValueToRect​(String str)
        Obtains the rectangle converted from the specified string based on the defined format.
        Parameters:
        str - Indicates the specified string.
        Returns:
        Returns the rectangle converted from the specified string.
        Since:
        5
